title: The pandemic has brought more automation, which could have long-term impacts for workers.
description: An increase in automation, especially in service industries, may prove to be an economic legacy of the pandemic.
content: An increase in automation, especially in service industries, may prove to be an economic legacy of the pandemic.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeffery C. Mays
title: Who is Maya Wiley?
description: Maya Wiley, a former counsel to Mayor Bill de Blasio and a former commentator on MSNBC, is in third place by a small margin after the early rounds of ranked-choice voting tabulation.
content: Maya Wiley, a former counsel to Mayor Bill de Blasio and a former commentator on MSNBC, is in third place by a small margin after the early rounds of ranked-choice voting tabulation.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Florence Fabricant
title: Dark Chocolates That Capture Summer’s Glory
description: “Fruit, Naturally” is a new line of vegan chocolates from the mind of the chocolatier Nicolas Cloiseau.
content: Ganache without cream? Nicolas Cloiseau, the award-winning head chocolatier of La Maison du Chocolat, is making them as part of his new line of vegan chocolates. The little dark chocolate rectangles, striped with color, are filled with fruit ganaches in five flavors: cassis (black currant), lemon, passion fruit, raspberry and chiberta (dark chocolate with orange). They make a good argument for enjoying dark chocolate in summer.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Florence Fabricant
title: Middle Eastern Dinners Delivered
description: Tanabel offers dinners and feasts, cooked by refugee women in Brooklyn.
content: Tanabel, named for Souk el Tanabel in Damascus, is Hannah Goldberg’s effort to employ refugee women from across the Middle East — including Syria, Iran and Lebanon — for dinners and events. The chef and culinary entrepreneur is not alone in this, but her business has grown over the past few years to the point where, earlier this year, she was able to move her production to a commercial kitchen. Her company prepares dinners for two delivered on Thursdays ($65) to central Brooklyn ($10 fee) or available for pick up; and feasts for two to three ($135) are available for Saturday delivery to most of Brooklyn, Queens and Manhattan ($10 to $15) or for pickup. Some condiments, dips and teas are also available on the website, $4 to $20. The menus change every week, though a recent Iranian dinner for two, including eggplant dip, a fresh vegetable and herb salad, flatbreads, chicken with sour plums and rice pilaf, and a creamy milk pudding for dessert was nothing short of delicious. As the company was closed for Fourth of July, the next delivery date is Saturday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Chris Colin
title: It’s Never Too Late to Learn How to Swim
description: Vijaya Srivastava, who lives in the San Francisco Bay Area, took her first swimming lesson at age 68. She’s now a daily swimmer.
content: “It’s Never Too Late” is a new series that tells the stories of people who decide to pursue their dreams on their own terms.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stanley Reed
title: Behind the Clash at OPEC: Growing Competition in the Gulf
description: The United Arab Emirates wants to pump more oil, annoying its giant rival, Saudi Arabia.
content: The fighting between the United Arab Emirates and Saudi Arabia that emerged in recent days over oil production had been brewing for months, if not years.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Futterman
title: She Protested on a Medal Podium. Will the Olympics Ban That?
description: The International Olympic Committee has loosened its rules on political speech at the Games. Olympic leaders in the United States and plenty of athletes say the changes don’t go far enough.
content: The American hammer throw athlete Gwen Berry, a contender for a medal at the Summer Olympics, has already raised her fist on a medal podium at a competition, and at the selection meet for the U.S. Olympic track team she turned away as the national anthem was played, drawing worldwide attention and debate.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julie Turkewitz
title: Colombian Military Leaders Accused of Assassinating Civilians in Civil War
description: The indictments, issued by a special court, say the military leaders falsely presented 120 victims as combatants in a bid to show the country was winning its long civil war.
content: BOGOTÁ, Colombia — A special court in Colombia has charged a general and other top military leaders with crimes against humanity, accusing them of assassinating 120 civilians and presenting the victims as combat casualties in a bid to show the country was winning its long civil war.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Futterman
title: Sha’Carri Richardson Will Miss Olympics After Not Being Chosen for Relays
description: The star sprinter, who lost a chance to run in the 100-meter individual event after failing a drug test for marijuana, could have been chosen for the relay team. But officials decided not to include her.
content: Sha’Carri Richardson, the American sprinter whose positive test result for marijuana cost her a spot in the women’s 100 meters at the Tokyo Olympics and ignited a debate about marijuana and sport, will miss the games entirely after being left off a relay team, American track officials announced Tuesday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeffery C. Mays
title: Kathryn Garcia, the former N.Y.C. sanitation commissioner, ran on her experience.
description: Kathryn Garcia, 51, the former sanitation commissioner, trailed Eric Adams by just one percentage point after after New York City’s Board of Elections released a new count on Tuesday evening that included tens of thousands of absentee ballots.
content: Kathryn Garcia, 51, the former sanitation commissioner, trailed Eric Adams by just one percentage point after after New York City’s Board of Elections released a new count on Tuesday evening that included tens of thousands of absentee ballots.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stanley Reed
title: Oil spikes to six-year highs and then falls back after OPEC Plus fails to reach a deal.
description: Traders worry that a deadlock means too little oil would reach the markets at a time of growing consumption as lockdowns ease and travel picks up.
content: Oil prices touched their highest levels in years on Tuesday, a day after OPEC, Russia and their allies failed yet again reach agreement on production increases. A teleconference planned for Monday never started, following meetings on Thursday and Friday that did not reach a deal.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rachel Fabi
title: The Way I See It …
description: Katie Hale sings a familiar refrain.
content: TUESDAY PUZZLE — Let’s give a hearty welcome to the constructor Katie Hale, who is making her debut with a puzzle you’re not likely to get out of your head anytime soon. Ms. Hale’s New York Times debut perfectly illustrates the type of puzzle that might result from noticing an incredible coincidence in the sights and, er, sounds around you. More about that coincidence, and the fabulous theme it generated, below.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shira Ovide
title: We Need Remote Work for Everyone
description: The ability to work online shouldn’t be a nice-to-have for a select few, but an option for all.
content: This article is part of the On Tech newsletter. You can sign up here to receive it weekdays.
source.name: The New York Times

title: The Rise of Delta
description: What we know about a coronavirus variant that is quickly becoming the most dominant and dangerous.
content: The Delta variant of the coronavirus is threatening to put the world in an entirely new stage of the pandemic.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elysa Gardner
title: With Venues Reopening Across New York, Life Is a Cabaret Once Again
description: The Great American Songbook, jazz, drag and more are returning to the small stages where intimacy and audience interaction are so key.
content: “Thank you all for risking your lives by coming out tonight,” Joe Iconis quipped, welcoming a socially distanced crowd to the June reopening of the cabaret venue Feinstein’s/54 Below in Manhattan.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Erin Woo
title: Work at Home or the Office? Either Way, There’s a Start-Up for That.
description: As more Americans return to an office a few days a week, start-ups providing tools for hybrid work are trying to cash in.
content: SAN FRANCISCO — Before the pandemic, Envoy, a start-up in San Francisco, sold visitor registration software for the office. Its system signed in guests and tracked who was coming into the building.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ashley Wong
title: Man Charged With Hate Crimes After Racist Tirade Is Caught on Video
description: Edward Cagney Mathews was recorded hurling racist harassment and challenging people to “come see me.” On Monday, his neighbors did just that, staging a protest outside his home.
content: A New Jersey man who was caught on video shouting racist insults and harassing his neighbors was arrested twice and charged with several hate crimes, with his second arrest coming as people staged an hourslong protest outside his home.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shauna Farnell
title: An Olympic Hurdle: Why Is the Decathlon Only for Men?
description: Chasing opportunity and equality, women are campaigning for their own 10-event competition, rather than just the heptathlon, at the Paris Games in 2024.
content: Jordan Gray wants to bring a women’s decathlon to the Olympics. Even if it happens long after she is able to compete in the event.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Sisario
title: Tyler, the Creator Hits No. 1 With ‘Call Me if You Get Lost’
description: The album opens with the equivalent of 169,000 sales, while BTS remains atop the singles chart with “Butter.”
content: Tyler, the Creator notches his second No. 1 on the Billboard album chart this week with “Call Me if You Get Lost,” while BTS remains atop the singles chart with “Butter.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Ross Sorkin, Jason Karaian, Sarah Kessler, Stephen Gandel, Michael J. de la Merced, Lauren Hirsch and Ephrat Livni
title: China Escalates Its Fight Against Big Tech
description: The latest targets include homegrown giants like Didi Chuxing.
content: Tensions are growing between China and tech companies inside — and outside — its borders.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jordan Allen, Kristen Bayrakdarian and Briana Scalia
title: Recent Commercial Real Estate Transactions
description: Recent commercial real estate transactions in New York.
content: $4.5 MILLION
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kari Molvar
title: In Praise of Sweat
description: In many cultures, perspiring is seen as integral to physical and spiritual well-being. The latest related holistic products respect this natural process, and smell good, too.
content: Sweating is often considered a nuisance, one that necessitates frequent mopping of brows or the rethinking of fashion choices on a steamy day. Yet, physiologically speaking, says Dr. Patricia Christie, a lecturer in chemistry and biology at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, it’s a thing of beauty. Sweating naturally occurs when the body’s core temperature exceeds a certain threshold (typically between 99 and 100 degrees), at which point the brain receives a signal that triggers the release of perspiration onto the skin. There, the beads of moisture — composed mostly of water, salt, potassium and trace minerals — evaporate, removing heat from the body and cooling it down, says Christie.
source.name: The New York Times

title: More Results Expected in the Mayor’s Race
description: Two weeks after New York City residents  cast ballots, elections officials are edging closer to a complete count.
content: [Want to get New York Today by email? Here’s the sign-up.]
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Manuel Betancourt
title: A New Novel Reinvents E.M. Forster’s Classic Gay Love Story ‘Maurice’
description: Forster’s novel featured a rare happy ending for gay characters. William di Canzio’s new book, “Alec,” picks up and continues their story.
content: ALECBy William di Canzio
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natasha Frost
title: Your Tuesday Briefing
description: England’s plan to remove restrictions.
content: Prime Minister Boris Johnson said on Monday that the government would very likely lift most remaining Covid rules in England on July 19 and leave it up to people to decide whether to keep wearing masks on public transportation and in confined spaces.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Tesla sales are way up, but Ford and others are still grappling with a semiconductor shortage.
description: Automakers are struggling to keep up with demand as a global shortage of computer chips is limits how many cars and trucks they can make.
content: Automakers are struggling to keep up with demand as a global shortage of computer chips is limits how many cars and trucks they can make.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Clio Chang
title: Screenshots Tell the Real Stories About Who We Are
description: When I’m curled up in bed at night and I want to reminisce, I go first to my screenshots folder, not my photo albums.
content: I believe that everyone collects something. Sometimes people’s beloved lots are obvious — when we visit my aunt in Taipei, we tease her for being unable to throw away any gift she has ever received. She is a former government official with big hair, which means the gifts are endless: expensive wines, jade sculptures, regional delicacies. Prominently displayed in her living room is a decorative pear with a lopsided portrait of her painted on it. Recently, when my aunt renovated, her daughter, desperate to seize on the opportunity to cleanse the apartment, asked to throw away a small Buddha statue that once belonged to my grandfather. My aunt told her to ask our grandmother, another collector, who told my exasperated cousin that for the sake of spiritual amity, she was allowed to dispose of the statue only in a rushing river.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Joe Coscarelli, Liz Day and Samantha Stark
title: Britney Spears’s Lawyer Asks to Step Down from Court-Appointed Role
description: The lawyer filed papers to withdraw after the singer said at a court hearing that she wanted new counsel to represent her and get her out of the conservatorship that governs her life.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jason Horowitz
title: Vatican History of Obfuscation Clouds News on Francis’ Health
description: While there was no reason to doubt the veracity of statements on the pope’s condition after colon surgery, the Vatican’s long lack of transparency has earned it skepticism.
content: The day after Pope John Paul II underwent a tracheotomy to relieve respiratory problems in 2005, the Vatican’s then spokesman told reporters that he had enjoyed a breakfast of 10 cookies. He died soon after.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Roslyn Sulcas
title: Processing the Pandemic at the Manchester International Festival
description: The annual arts event in the north of England suggests that focusing on community and inclusiveness could be a natural, post-pandemic outcome for artists.
content: MANCHESTER, England — “Your City, Your Festival.” The slogan is emblazoned on the 2,000-odd posters strung up around the city center here, above pictures of ethnically diverse faces of various genders and ages. That would be the Manchester International Festival, which, against considerable odds, in a region of England particularly affected by the pandemic, opened on schedule on July 1. (It runs through July 18.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rick Rojas and Sophie Kasakove
title: ‘Should We Sell?’ After Collapse, Hot Florida Market Faces Uncertainty.
description: The partial collapse of the Champlain Towers South in Surfside, Fla., has plunged older beachside condos and high-rise buildings like it into a swirl of apprehension.
content: SURFSIDE, Fla. — Ines Mason bought the 14th-floor condo in a building perched on an island in Biscayne Bay five years ago as a getaway, lured by the captivating view of the water. “In the morning, the sun rises, you can see that,” she said. “It’s amazing.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kathryn Shattuck
title: H.E.R. Still Finds Inspiration in Prince and ‘Martin’
description: The Grammy- and Oscar-winning performer talks about her new album, the moment she knew she wanted to be a rock star and why R&B isn’t dead.
content: H.E.R. doesn’t want her music to be boxed in.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dara Kell and Veena Rao
title: He Is Imprisoned at Guantánamo. Making Art Is His Escape.
description: Moath al-Alwi has never been charged with a crime, but has spent over 19 years at the U.S. military detention camp in Cuba. In a new short film, Mr. al-Alwi talks about the art he makes to survive.
content: We first came across Moath al-Alwi’s artwork when we heard about an exhibition at John Jay College of Criminal Justice titled “Ode to the Sea,” which featured works made by current and former detainees at Guantánamo Bay. When we saw Mr. al-Alwi’s model ships, we were struck by how stunningly detailed they were, especially given the limited materials available within the prison.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Coral Murphy Marcos
title: Gas prices are expected to keep climbing through August.
description: High demand and a lack of a deal among oil producers to raise production are contributing to the increase. AAA expects prices to rise as much as 20 cents a gallon by the end of next month.
content: AAA said on Tuesday that gas prices were expected to increase another 10 to 20 cents through the end of August.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emma Copley Eisenberg
title: ‘Worse Than a Prison’: Hospitals for the Criminally Insane
description: “Couple Found Slain,” by Mikita Brottman, offers an accounting of the criminal mental health system.
content: COUPLE FOUND SLAINAfter a Family MurderBy Mikita Brottman
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Glenn Thrush and Alan Rappeport
title: States and Cities Scramble to Spend $350 Billion Windfall
description: The Biden administration is betting on the funds to keep the recovery humming, but Republicans say the money is being wasted.
content: WASHINGTON — When Steve Adler, the mayor of Austin, heard the Biden administration planned to give billions of dollars to states and localities in the $1.9 trillion pandemic aid package, he knew exactly what he wanted to do with his cut.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carl Zimmer
title: The world is worried about the Delta virus variant. Studies show vaccines are effective against it.
description: Israel reported that the Pfizer vaccine was 64 percent effective against the Delta variant. Other studies suggest a higher rate.
content: As the Delta variant sweeps the world, researchers are tracking how well vaccines protect against it — and getting different answers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Chris Hamby
title: Biotech Company That Botched Vaccines Faces Investor Revolt
description: In the latest shareholder lawsuit, a pension fund accused executives at Emergent BioSolutions of insider trading. The company, under investigation by Congress, has halted manufacturing of Covid-19 vaccines at its Baltimore factory at regulators’ request.
content: Last summer, investors flocked to the biotech company Emergent BioSolutions. The host of CNBC’s “Mad Money,” Jim Cramer, gushed about the Maryland business, which had secured a lucrative government contract to manufacture Covid-19 vaccines for Johnson & Johnson and AstraZeneca.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mara Altman
title: Happy? Sad? Stressed? How Drinking Became the Answer to Everything
description: Alcohol has become so normalized there’s hardly a situation when a drink doesn’t feel appropriate, experts say. Now we’re marketing it to one another.
content: — Emily Lynn Paulson, the founder of Sober Mom Squad, on how alcohol seems to be the answer for every occasion
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Luis Ferré-Sadurní
title: New York’s Fiscal Watchdog Sues to End Mayor’s Pandemic Spending Powers
description: The city comptroller, Scott Stringer, wants to regain oversight of the city’s pandemic spending, which he said has been characterized by “overpayment and overpurchasing.”
content: As New York City hospitals filled up at the height of the pandemic last year, Mayor Bill de Blasio suspended the city’s procurement rules, signing an emergency executive order that gave the city greater flexibility to move quickly to purchase lifesaving medical supplies.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Florence Fabricant
title: Umami With a Momofuku Touch
description: The chef David Chang’s Momofuku brand now sells “restaurant-grade” versions of soy sauce, sesame oil and tamari.
content: To its rapidly expanding inventory of pantry products, Momofuku has now added some commonplace staples: toasted sesame oil, soy sauce and tamari. The oil is cold-pressed, and the soy sauce and the gluten-free tamari are steeped in kombu, to give them elements of complexity and umami, not just salinity.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Florence Fabricant
title: Angie Mar’s Latest, Les Trois Chevaux, Opens
description: A community-supported agriculture program puts down roots, Levantine cuisine in Chelsea, and more restaurant news.
content: Angie Mar is entering a new stage of her career with the opening of this elegant tribute to fine dining. “This is my restaurant, not something I inherited, and I was looking for fresh ideas,” she said. Previously, she was the chef and owner at the Beatrice Inn next door, which she acquired from Graydon Carter. (That restaurant closed this year, and Ms. Mar subsequently decided to open this new place instead of recreating the Beatrice.) Now, defying current restaurant norms — bare tables, no dress code, a burger on the menu — this venture features white napery beneath a chandelier that came from the Waldorf Astoria, a French menu that tilts classic and the requirement that men wear jackets (with a supply of vintage YSL on hand). Though Ms. Mar is known for her artistry with slabs of meat, she isn’t offering steak, preferring seafood and birds. “It’s a vast departure, but what I want right now,” she said. The prix-fixe menu ($185) will change frequently but digs deep into French tradition with frog legs and artichokes in beurre blanc, a mousse of veal brains with truffles, sweetbreads wrapped in cabbage, Dover sole with sorrel mousseline, pithiviers (a pastry dome) of crab, and roast pheasant for two. There will be a croquembouche for dessert. Her inspiration comes from chefs like André Soltner and Jacques Pépin; a painting by Mr. Pépin hangs near the bar. Except for a Hungarian Tokay, the wine list is all French and American, and the salonlike room seats 37, plus nine at the bar. Banquettes in inky blue, which Ms. Mar said was the color of her father’s favorite sweatshirt, contrast the creamy ivory of the walls, and touches of that shade show up in the staff’s Christian Siriano-designed outfits. The restaurant’s name, which translates to the three horses, is a nod to what her family called her and her two brothers. (Opens Thursday)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Thomas Erdbrink and Claire Moses
title: Prominent Dutch Crime Reporter Is Shot in Center of Amsterdam
description: Peter R. de Vries, famous for solving cold cases and hosting his own televised crime show, was shot in the head and fighting for his life Tuesday night. His reporting regularly drew death threats.
content: AMSTERDAM — A well-known Dutch crime reporter was shot in the head on Tuesday night after leaving a TV studio in the center of Amsterdam, the police said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Constant Méheut
title: France Drops Plans to Enshrine Climate Fight in Constitution
description: The announcement marked a setback for President Emmanuel Macron, who had framed the constitutional change as the symbolic backbone of his environmental policies.
content: PARIS — The French government on Tuesday said that it would drop its plans to enshrine the fight against climate change in the Constitution, effectively giving up on what was seen as a major step in the country’s environmental commitments.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Joanne Kaufman
title: Constructing the Perfect Villain: The Bad Contractor
description: In her latest crime novel, Megan Abbott takes on the contractor-client relationship. In her Queens apartment, she’s avoided renovation altogether.
content: More perhaps than most, Megan Abbott knows what evil lurks in the hearts of men (and women, too). This explains Ms. Abbott’s ability to conjure the perfect bad guy — ahem, a contractor — in her latest crime novel, the ballet-centric thriller, “The Turnout,” which will be published Aug. 3.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rory Smith
title: Italy Bars the Door and Keeps the Party Going
description: Reverting to type after a Euro 2020 filled with fun, Italy locked down on defense and then defeated Spain on penalties to reach the final.
content: LONDON — Jorginho stood in front of the massed ranks of Italy’s fans, straightened his back and took a breath. Every single one of them knew what was coming. So, too, did Unai Simón, Spain’s goalkeeper, fidgeting and flickering with nervous energy on his line.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Edgar Sandoval
title: In Disaster City, Texas, Rescues Are a Way of Life
description: Emergency workers like those combing through the remains of the condo building in Surfside, Fla., come to East Texas to learn how to save people trapped in rubble.
content: COLLEGE STATION, Texas — Moments after a high-rise condominium building in Surfside, Fla., was nearly leveled in a devastating collapse late last month, emergency workers began sifting through concrete and twisted metal for any sign of survivors.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mark Landler
title: Steeped in Soccer Heartbreak, England Holds Its Breath
description: Raised on 55 years of disappointment, English fans are daring to hope this might be their year for a major championship.
content: LONDON — Football’s coming home, and England is rejoicing in spite of itself.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dana Smith
title: What to Look for in a Physical Therapist
description: Not all P.T.s are created equal. Find a professional who values evidence over anecdote.
content: There’s been a quiet revolution taking place in the field of physical therapy. In the early 2000s, you could go to five different physical therapists for an injury and receive five different treatment plans. Some would have advised targeted exercises to strengthen muscles or classic treatments, like heat and cold packs.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Casselman and Clifford Krauss
title: Rising Oil and Gas Prices Add to U.S. Economic Challenges
description: Experts say a period of costlier fuel is likely to be brief. But if consumers start to assume otherwise, it could mean problems for Biden and the Fed.
content: As the U.S. economy struggles to emerge from its pandemic-induced hibernation, consumers and businesses have encountered product shortages, hiring difficulties and often conflicting public health guidance, among other challenges.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Gold
title: The Elections Board resets its deadline (again), promising results by 7:30 p.m. Eastern.
description: After hours of ambiguity in which reporters, candidates and political analysts were constantly refreshing results pages looking for any changes, the city’s Board of Elections said on Tuesday afternoon that it would release a new ranked-choice tally in the Democratic primary for mayor by 7:30 p.m.
content: After hours of ambiguity in which reporters, candidates and political analysts were constantly refreshing results pages looking for any changes, the city’s Board of Elections said on Tuesday afternoon that it would release a new ranked-choice tally in the Democratic primary for mayor by 7:30 p.m.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Catherine Hickley
title: Did the Nazis Force an Art Sale? The Question Lingers 88 Years Later.
description: The case of Curt Glaser, an art historian who sold his collection before fleeing Germany, illustrates how differently museums can respond to similar restitution claims.
content: The Nazi authorities removed Curt Glaser from his post as director of the Berlin State Art Library in April 1933 because he was Jewish. He was also evicted from his home and, the following month, sold most of his art collection at two auctions.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexis Soloski
title: Hot Vax Summer? Falstaff and Shakespeare in the Park Are Ready.
description: The Delacorte Theater in Central Park is reopening with a Harlem-set version of Shakespeare’s comedy “The Merry Wives of Windsor.”
content: At the first rehearsal for “Merry Wives,” the playwright Jocelyn Bioh told a story. In the first months of her undergraduate acting program, she said, a professor had scrutinized her look, listened to her accent and decided that Shakespeare was not for her. “I was told that none of my Blackness, none of my Africanness, none of my New Yorkness was allowed to be a part of Shakespeare in any way,” said Bioh, a child of Ghanaian immigrants.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Brace yourselves: Italy will be counting on its defense as usual.
description: It should not surprise anyone that Italy has been one of the toughest teams to score against in the tournament: The Italians often are, and they have conceded only two goals in their five games this summer, and only one from the run of play. (Only England, which has yet to surrender a goal, has been better.)
content: It should not surprise anyone that Italy has been one of the toughest teams to score against in the tournament: The Italians often are, and they have conceded only two goals in their five games this summer, and only one from the run of play. (Only England, which has yet to surrender a goal, has been better.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maya Phillips
title: In ‘What to Send Up,’ I See You, Black American Theater
description: Our critic reflects on the significance of Aleshea Harris’s play, at BAM Fisher, for Black audiences.
content: We didn’t know what to do about this piece.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isabel Kershner
title: Israel’s New Government Fails to Extend Contentious Citizenship Law
description: In an early setback for Prime Minister Naftali Bennett, parts of his coalition opposed the law. The opposition refused to come to the rescue.
content: JERUSALEM — In a setback for Israel’s three-week-old government, it failed to muster a majority on Tuesday to extend a contentious law that effectively bans citizenship or permanent residency for Palestinians from the occupied territories who marry Israelis.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Gordon
title: A Spy Thriller That Mixes Fact and Fiction to Harrowing Effect
description: Featuring a C.I.A. agent with secrets in her past, potentially violent religious extremists and a risky op in Hamburg, “The Cover Wife,” by Dan Fesperman, gives imaginative twists to events plucked from our near past.
content: THE COVER WIFEBy Dan Fesperman
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Reuters
title: Honduras Court Convicts Ex-Dam Executive in Murder of Celebrated Environmentalist
description: Roberto David Castillo, the former head of the company that was building a hydroelectric dam on Indigenous land in Honduras, was found guilty of being a co-conspirator in the murder of Berta Caceres.
content: TEGUCIGALPA, Honduras — A former top executive of a Honduran construction firm was found guilty on Monday of being a collaborator in the 2016 murder of the Indigenous environmental activist Berta Caceres, a judge said in a court ruling.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Gold
title: How ranked-choice voting can reshape an election.
description: Many New York City voters got their first glimpse at how ranked-choice voting can reshape an election last week, when the Board of Elections released a preliminary tally of ranked-choice election results.
content: Many New York City voters got their first glimpse at how ranked-choice voting can reshape an election last week, when the Board of Elections released a preliminary tally of ranked-choice election results.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maggie Astor
title: Why New York’s Election Debacle Is Likely to Fuel Conspiracy Theories
description: Republicans have seized on the botched release of results from the mayor’s race — but the overall effect on public trust goes deeper.
content: It has been one week since the New York City Board of Elections botched the release of preliminary ranked-choice tabulations from the city’s mayoral race, counting 135,000 dummy ballots that employees had used to test a computer system and then failed to delete.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emma G. Fitzsimmons
title: Here’s what to expect from Tuesday’s tally in the N.Y.C. mayor’s race.
description: The new results should include most of the roughly 125,000 Democratic absentee ballots, which were not included in last week’s count.
content: New York City’s Board of Elections will release a new tally of votes in the Democratic primary for mayor on Tuesday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Pete Wells
title: The Restaurant of This New York Summer Is Outerspace
description: Two avidly followed pop-ups, Ha’s Dac Biet and Kreung, have taken over the wood fires and the picnic tables of this seasonal venue in Brooklyn.
content: This is the summer of boozy, brightly colored cocktails in big, sweaty plastic cups. It is the summer of eating under potted palms and banana trees that move languidly in the breeze, when there is a breeze. It is the summer of meals interrupted by showers and thunderstorms and struggles to open patio umbrellas. It is the summer of meticulously prepared $40 main courses served in compostable paper bowls with sauce in a separate plastic container.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Rothenberg
title: At Wimbledon, the Women’s Final Four Is Set
description: No. 8 seed Karolina Pliskova will face No. 2 Aryna Sabalenka, and No. 1 Ashleigh Barty will play No. 25 Angelique Kerber on Thursday, for a chance to make the women’s singles final at Wimbledon.
content: WIMBLEDON, England — Karolina Pliskova, the only woman to reach this year’s Wimbledon semifinals without dropping a set, is learning to appreciate what she’s done, rather than dwelling on what she hasn’t.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dan Bilefsky
title: Trudeau Appoints Canada’s First Indigenous Governor General
description: The appointment of Mary Simon, a former ambassador, comes as Canada grapples with the discovery of hundreds of unmarked graves, mainly of Indigenous children.
content: MONTREAL — Prime Minister Justin Trudeau appointed Canada’s first Indigenous governor general on Tuesday, a move with wide symbolic resonance as the country seeks to reconcile with its Indigenous population after decades of systemic mistreatment.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Gold
title: Democratic primary turnout, the strongest in years, was just 26 percent. The Republican vote was even tinier.
description: A number of bitterly fought races in the 1970s and 1980s saw greater turnout.
content: With one of the most competitive mayor’s races in recent memory and a number of hotly contested down-ballot primaries, the turnout in last month’s Democratic mayoral primary in New York City was the strongest in years.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Schmall and Karan Deep Singh
title: ‘Don’t Sacrifice Your Life to Visit the Taj Mahal’: India Reopens but Fear Pervades
description: As India emerges from a traumatic spring, its most famous monument is open again. But worries that another wave of infections may be looming have cast a pall over lives that feel stuck in limbo.
content: AGRA, India — From a rickety fishing boat on the Yamuna River, Sumit Chaurasia points out how the setting tangerine sun catches the sparkle of the mother-of-pearl embedded in the Taj Mahal, India’s majestic monument to love.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicole Perlroth and David E. Sanger
title: Attempted Hack of R.N.C. and Russian Ransomware Attack Test Biden
description: The breach of a Republican National Committee contractor, also linked to Russia, and the global ransomware attack occurred weeks after a U.S.-Russian summit.
content: Russian hackers are accused of breaching a contractor for the Republican National Committee last week, around the same time that Russian cybercriminals launched the single largest global ransomware attack on record, incidents that are testing the red lines set by President Biden during his high-stakes summit with President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia last month.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Joshua Barone
title: Opera Roars Back With Dueling Wagner Premieres
description: After a long absence of large-scale productions, there are two major new “Tristan und Isolde” stagings running in Germany and France.
content: If you were watching closely, opera never truly disappeared during the pandemic.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Florence Fabricant
title: A Better Way to Blister Peppers
description: The kozmatik, a Turkish tool used to blacken eggplant, is a perfect summer gadget.
content: Here’s a gadget that might become essential for summer and beyond. The kozmatik is used in Turkey for searing eggplants for baba ganoush to give them that lovely smoky allure, as well as for peppers, zucchini and other vegetables. It’s simple and effective: Radiating slits allow heat and some flames from a gas burner or a barbecue grill to lick at the vegetable’s skin, easily blackening it as you gradually turn it with tongs. It doesn’t work on an electric cooktop. It’s easy to clean and, at about the size of a pie plate, storage should not be a problem.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vanessa Friedman
title: Reunited (at Dior) and It Feels So Good?
description: We’re back to body parts, discos and sky dives. Yes, it’s showtime, in a mix of digital and physical, at Schiaparelli, Iris van Herpen and Giambattista Valli.
content: PARIS — “It’s like a school reunion, no?” said Carine Roitfeld, the French fashion editor, flicking her veil of hair off her black-lined eyes and glancing around at the Dior show on Monday. The gang was back, in a specially constructed box, as always, in the gardens of the Musée Rodin, as attendees who had not seen each other in person in more than a year air-kissed and embraced in delight. Ms. Roitfeld looked bemused, and not entirely pleased.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Scott Borchert
title: A New Deal for Writers in America
description: Writers suffered enormously during the pandemic. The Federal Writers’ Project offers a template on how to help them — and the country.
content: Nearly eight decades ago, the Federal Writers’ Project — the literary division of the New Deal’s vast jobs creation program — met an untimely demise at the hands of its enemies in Congress. Now it seems that Congress may invite its resurrection.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maura Turcotte
title: Virus cases are surging at crowded immigration detention centers in the U.S.
description: With more migrants being detained at the borders, centers run by ICE are seeing a rise in infections. Few detainees are vaccinated.
content: As their populations swell nearly to prepandemic levels, U.S. immigration detention centers are reporting major surges in coronavirus infections among detainees.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Aurelien Breeden
title: A French Teenager’s Anti-Islam Rant Unleashed Death Threats. Now 13 Are on Trial.
description: The court case is about online harassment, but it also touches on some of France’s most sensitive issues: freedom of expression and blasphemy.
content: PARIS — The French girl, 16, was sharing highly personal details about her life in a livestream on Instagram, including her attraction to women. Just not Black or Arab women, she said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James Poniewozik
title: ‘I Think You Should Leave’ Gives Us the Jerks We Deserve
description: Tim Robinson’s sketch show returns with more painfully recognizable losers (and more hot dogs).
content: In 2019, Tim Robinson entered the conversation through a door that opened the wrong way.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jennifer Szalai
title: Democracy Is for Losers (and Why That’s a Good Thing)
description: In “Democracy Rules,” Jan-Werner Müller emphasizes uncertainty as an essential part of democracy, alongside the more familiar principles of liberty and equality.
content: Staring down a big shelf of big Trump books, I’m beginning to wonder if — when it comes to helping us understand the full import of what happened during his four years in the White House — less may very well be more. The 400-page catalogs of ruthless betrayals, nasty insults and erratic tweets add to our store of knowledge mainly by compounding what’s already there; a slender volume of political theory, on the other hand, can prompt us to rethink our assumptions, raising central questions that we never properly asked before.
source.name: The New York Times

title: No Corrections: July 6, 2021
description: No corrections appeared in print on Tuesday, July 6, 2021.
content: Errors are corrected during the press run whenever possible, so some errors noted here may not have appeared in all editions.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Das
title: Denmark’s Christian Eriksen has been invited to Sunday’s final.
description: UEFA invited Eriksen, the Danish star who collapsed on the field during his team’s first game, and the paramedics who saved his life.
content: Christian Eriksen and the paramedics who helped save his life after he collapsed on the field during Denmark’s first game at Euro 2020 have been invited to attend Sunday’s final in London by UEFA, the tournament’s organizer.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Shpigel
title: Montreal Canadiens Win in Overtime to Force Game 5 in Tampa Bay
description: The Lightning scored late in the third period to tie the game at 2-2 but Montreal forward Josh Anderson ended the game with a goal that postponed Tampa’s Stanley Cup celebration.
content: The Montreal Canadiens did not win the first game of the Stanley Cup finals, or the second, or the third, and as the fourth careered toward overtime on Monday night a familiar feeling settled in their dressing room.
source.name: The New York Times

title: A German referee will be in charge of Italy vs. Spain.
description: Today’s referee is a German, Felix Brych, who will be familiar to players on both teams from his work in the Champions League.
content: Today’s referee is a German, Felix Brych, who will be familiar to players on both teams from his work in the Champions League.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jillian Medoff
title: An Office Novel That Dares to Think Outside the Cubicle
description: In “The Very Nice Box,” set at an Ikea-like furniture company, Laura Blackett and Eve Gleichman deliver workplace drama with a twist.
content: THE VERY NICE BOXBy Laura Blackett and Eve Gleichman
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katherine E. Standefer
title: In Nature, a Biologist Finds an Unlikely Companion
description: “Fox & I” is Catherine Raven’s memoir of her relationship with a bushy-tailed creature — no, not a dog.
content: FOX & IAN UNCOMMON FRIENDSHIPBY CATHERINE RAVEN
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Phillip Atiba Goff and Katie Porter
title: A Mental Health Crisis Is Not a Crime
description: Congress can give cities and towns more ways to respond to people in trouble.
content: Every 10 years, following a national census, the Constitution requires states to draw districts for each of the newly reapportioned 435 seats in the House of Representatives. Since districts were last drawn in 2011, law enforcement officers have killed a person in every one of them.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Malia Wollan
title: How to Collect Greywater
description: In the face of historic droughts and climate change, find a way to proactively do something.
content: “Greywater is gently used water,” says Laura Allen, 45, who lives in Eugene, Ore., in a duplex where water draining from a washing machine, showers and sinks is piped out to irrigate blueberry bushes, fruit trees, flowers and ornamental bushes. This type of household wastewater, which does not come in contact with feces, can be reused to water plants. Check regional greywater laws. Its use is legal in about half the country, especially in Western states, and even encouraged by the authorities.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Wolfe and Amelia Nierenberg
title: Coronavirus Briefing: What Happened Today
description: Cases in New York City remain low, even though less than half of city residents are fully vaccinated.
content: These past few weekends, New York City has really seemed to come alive. People are gathering unmasked in bars and restaurants, parks and beaches are full of picnics and parties, and foot traffic all over the city has seemed to pick up.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Leonhardt
title: A Supreme Court, Transformed
description: A Supreme Court altered by Donald Trump is coming into focus. We look at where it’s headed.
content: The latest version of the Supreme Court — with Donald Trump’s three appointees — is starting to come into focus. It is both ideologically predictable and unpredictable, depending on the issue.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ruth Graham
title: ‘Sermongate’ Prompts a Quandary: Should Pastors Borrow Words From One Another?
description: The new leader of the Southern Baptist Convention has delivered sermons containing passages from those of his predecessor, causing a furor.
content: The similarities in the sermons are unmistakable.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Wesley Morris
title: Jam & Lewis Shaped Pop History. They’re Working on Its Future, Too.
description: The writing and production duo Jimmy Jam and Terry Lewis helped give Janet Jackson and others decades of hits. Now they’re bringing their “newstalgic” sound to their own LP.
content: Has this ever happened to you? You’re at a party or dinner or the gym, when out of nowhere, the person you’re talking to stops speaking. They look around as if they’re being called, which is funny because you don’t hear an emergency. Just Cheryl Lynn’s 1983 R&B hit “Encore.” They run to the dance floor. They make their own dance floor — right there in that restaurant, that bodega, that Target.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jenny Gross
title: Nikole Hannah-Jones will join Howard University instead of the University of North Carolina.
description: Ms. Hannah-Jones will start a journalism center at Howard University, one of the country’s leading historically Black colleges and universities. U.N.C.’s board of trustees had failed to consider tenure for her until she threatened legal action.
content: The Pulitzer Prize-winning journalist Nikole Hannah-Jones said on Tuesday that she would join the faculty of Howard University, a surprise announcement less than a week after the University of North Carolina’s board of trustees voted to grant her tenure, reversing its earlier decision.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kaya Laterman
title: Instead of Bingo, Senior Housing Brings Opera Singers and Broadway Insiders to Residents
description: New York senior communities take advantage of the city’s cultural institutions by inviting artists and experts to their facilities.
content: Enrichment classes are a dime a dozen in retirement facilities, but a crop of high-end senior living communities in New York City is offering next-level workshops, taught by local artists and experts from local museums and cultural institutions.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jennifer Steinhauer
title: Unlikely Coalition of Veterans Backs Biden on Ending Afghan War
description: A politically diverse set of veterans’ groups critical of the conflicts abroad have found ways to gain access to the White House to lobby for withdrawals.
content: WASHINGTON — Soon after President Biden announced that the United States military would withdraw from Afghanistan, hawks in Congress accused him of accepting defeat. But a diverse group of war veterans — many of whom had clashed bitterly with one another over the years — stepped in to provide him political cover.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: As Wildfires Surge, Even Lush Hawaii Faces a Different World
description: Quotation of the Day for Tuesday, July 6, 2021.
content: “The fire got all the way to the horse pasture before the dozers came and cut it off. Something like this was unheard-of around here when I was growing up. Now it’s a different world.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eric A. Taub
title: The Continuing Confusion Over Airline Travel Credits
description: “Who has eight hours to call an online travel agent?” asked one of many frustrated would-be travelers encountering delays and confusing rules when rebooking flights.
content: To witness her son’s graduation from the National Guard’s Apache helicopter training program in April 2020, Janet Chen used Expedia to book what she thought was a round-trip ticket on Delta Air Lines from her home in Wake Forest, N.C., to Dothan Airport in Alabama. When the pandemic made travel dangerous, she canceled her trip and received a voucher for its full $500 value, to be used within 18 months.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vivian Wang
title: An Officer Stabbed. A Bomb Plot Foiled. A Specter of Violence Divides Hong Kong.
description: Six teenagers were among those arrested in connection with a bomb plot. Some democracy activists say Beijing’s crackdown is fueling radical ideas.
content: HONG KONG — Last week in Hong Kong, on the politically sensitive anniversary of the city’s return to China, a man stabbed a police officer on a busy commercial street, then killed himself.
source.name: The New York Times

title: New & Noteworthy, From Quentin Tarantino to Comic Essays of Female Friendship
description: A selection of books published this week; plus, a peek at what our colleagues around the newsroom are reading.
content: ONCE UPON A TIME IN HOLLYWOOD, by Quentin Tarantino. (Harper Perennial/HarperCollins, paper, $9.99.) Tarantino’s first novel is based on his Oscar-winning 2019 film, with some notable departures; think of it as the director’s cut novelization.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Abrams
title: What It Means to Be Clutch in Basketball’s Biggest Moments
description: Legends are made in the N.B.A. finals, which begin Tuesday. Basketball players who have come through in high-stakes moments like this explain how they did it.
content: They are the moments dreamed about in childhood while on an empty playground. An imaginary game clock dwindles. A couple of dribbles are taken. A game-winning shot is launched.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Victor Mather
title: Another Famous Name at the Olympics: Springsteen
description: Jessica Springsteen, the daughter of Bruce Springsteen and Patti Scialfa, is ranked 27th in the world in show jumping and has a good chance to win a medal.
content: Kent Farrington, Laura Kraut and McLain Ward were named to the American show jumping team for the equestrian events at the Tokyo Olympics.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Jeff Bezos steps down as Amazon’s C.E.O., handing the reins to Andy Jassy.
description: Andy Jassy was elevated to chief executive of Amazon on Monday, taking the reins from its founder, Jeff Bezos, in one of the most closely watched executive handoffs in years.
content: Andy Jassy was elevated to chief executive of Amazon on Monday, taking the reins from its founder, Jeff Bezos, in one of the most closely watched executive handoffs in years.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Florence Fabricant
title: A Sparkling Book of Inspiration
description: “Gazoz” is a new cookbook that explores a genre of carbonated nonalcoholic drinks.
content: A gazoz is a carbonated nonalcoholic drink, but it becomes a refreshing still life, ready to sip, in the hands of Benny Briga, the Tel Aviv restaurateur who serves an array of them at his Café Levinsky. His new book, “Gazoz,” written with Adeena Sussman, shows you the necessary ingredients and how they are constructed. Mr. Briga ferments fruits in sugar for his drinks, a requirement for many but not all the recipes. Homemade fruit and vegetable syrups, nut butters, edible flowers and herbs all figure into the magical beauty of his glasses of gazoz, pictured throughout the book. He provides specific recipes for peach, cherry, watermelon, tomato and scores of other flavors, including a rose gazoz. They are at once fragrantly subtle and richly complex. And after you’ve finished the drink his advice is: “Eat the fruit.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Yu Young Jin
title: White flags fly in Malaysia as hunger spreads during lockdown.
description: With a fourth lockdown in place, tens of thousands of Malaysians have lost their jobs. A campaign is expressing dissatisfaction with the government.
content: Signs of economic distress have begun appearing in neighborhoods across Kuala Lumpur and other Malaysian cities: white flags outside people’s houses, indicating that they need food or other assistance.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maggie Astor
title: How G.O.P.-Backed Laws in Montana Could Hurt Native American Voting
description: Restrictions passed by the Republican-led Montana Legislature could have stark effects on Native American reservations, where voting in person can mean a two-hour drive.
content: STARR SCHOOL, Mont. — One week before the 2020 election, Laura Roundine had emergency open-heart surgery. She returned to her home on the Blackfeet Indian Reservation with blunt instructions: Don’t go anywhere while you recover, because if you get Covid-19, you’ll probably die.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Remy Tumin
title: Gas Prices, Afghanistan, N.B.A. Finals: Your Tuesday Evening Briefing
description: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
content: (Want to get this newsletter in your inbox? Here’s the sign-up.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anton Troianovski
title: Plane Crashes in Russia With 28 People Aboard
description: The aircraft was flying a regional route in the far eastern peninsula of Kamchatka. There were not believed to be any survivors, Russian news agencies reported.
content: MOSCOW — A passenger plane with 28 people aboard crashed in far eastern Russia on Tuesday, the authorities said, in the latest blow to the country’s sprawling but aging domestic aviation industry.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael M. Grynbaum
title: Fox’s New Channel Changes the Climate for Weather TV
description: As viewers tune out cable news, Rupert Murdoch is preparing the debut of Fox Weather, a potentially powerful new player in a sphere long dominated by the Weather Channel.
content: Weather is taking the media industry by storm.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Li Yuan
title: For China’s Business Elites, Staying Out of Politics Is No Longer an Option
description: The fallout from Beijing’s crackdown on the ride-hailing app Didi has ensnared even those who made it a point to not mix business with politics.
content: Liu Chuanzhi, the founder of the tech company Lenovo and a towering figure in China’s private sector, has long held the view that businesspeople should steer clear of politics. Yet he recently found out firsthand that in President Xi Jinping’s China, which is engaged in a tech cold war with the United States, business cannot just be business.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Joanna Rakoff
title: A Wife and Mother Finds a New House and Decides to Move in Alone
description: Dana Spiotta’s new novel explores a middle-aged fantasy of solitude to great effect.
content: WAYWARDBy Dana Spiotta
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Luke Broadwater
title: Capitol Police plan to open field offices outside Washington to track threats to lawmakers.
description: The agency charged with protecting Congress is transforming itself in the wake of the Jan. 6 attack, which exposed serious deficiencies in training and preparedness.
content: Six months after a mob of supporters of President Donald J. Trump stormed the Capitol, the United States Capitol Police is planning to expand operations outside Washington in an effort to better protect lawmakers, beginning with the opening of field offices in California and Florida.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Caleb Azumah Nelson
title: Debut Novels by Jesse McCarthy, Gabriel Krauze and Mohamed Mbougar Sarr
description: New fiction spans gang violence in London, a fundamentalist regime in North Africa, Brooklyn gentrification and the Black diaspora in Brazil.
content: WHO THEY WAS By Gabriel Krauze 331 pp. Bloomsbury. $26.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Linda Baker
title: Native American Tribes Move to Make Real Estate a Force for Renewal
description: Despite high barriers to entry, tribal leaders are finding more investment opportunities to expand beyond casino revenue and to help their communities.
content: Native Americans have been systematically dispossessed of their ancestral lands for more than a century, thanks to federal land-management policies. But a spate of new real estate projects highlights efforts to reclaim that territory, as tribes invest in land development in an effort to diversify their revenue base and support their members.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gretchen Reynolds
title: Do We Really Need to Take 10,000 Steps a Day for Our Health?
description: The advice that we take 10,000 steps a day is more a marketing accident than based on science. Taking far fewer may have notable benefits.
content: Fitness tracking devices often recommend we take 10,000 steps a day. But the goal of taking 10,000 steps, which many of us believe is rooted in science, in fact rests on coincidence and sticky history rather than research.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jill Cowan
title: Images of Independence Day From Across California
description: Tuesday: A newly reopened state celebrates.
content: Good morning.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lucy Scholes
title: A Novel Follows Intersecting Lives on London’s Margins
description: Keith Ridgway’s “A Shock” initially looks like a collection of loosely linked stories, but reveals itself to be an expertly built house of mirrors.
content: A SHOCKBy Keith Ridgway
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicole Sperling
title: They Resurrected MGM. Amazon Bought the Studio. Now What?
description: Michael De Luca and Pamela Abdy have reinvigorated a once-storied Hollywood institution. Now it needs to figure out its place in a streaming company.
content: Paul Thomas Anderson and Michael De Luca are film geeks with a shared history. As a studio executive, Mr. De Luca championed Mr. Anderson’s “Boogie Nights” and “Magnolia,” films that established the director’s reputation as a creative force. So when Focus Features said it would postpone the production of Mr. Anderson’s new film because of the pandemic, it was Mr. De Luca, in his new role as chairman of MGM’s Motion Picture Group, who swooped in and pledged to get the movie into production in Los Angeles when Mr. Anderson wanted to shoot.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kate Conger and David E. Sanger
title: Pentagon Cancels a Disputed $10 Billion Technology Contract
description: The decision puts an end to years of legal wrangling over the contract, for 10 years of cloud-computing services.
content: The Defense Department said on Tuesday that it would not go forward with a lucrative cloud-computing contract that had become the subject of a contentious legal battle amid claims of interference by the Trump administration.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ashley Southall
title: Cuomo Declares a Gun Violence Emergency in New York State
description: The governor allocated $139 million to address shootings that are rising even as the pandemic recedes and to create jobs for young people.
content: Not long after the coronavirus bore down on New York last year, gun violence surged, rising 75 percent or more in some of the state’s largest cities. But even as the virus receded in recent months, shootings continued to rise.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Megan Specia
title: U.K. Proposes Moving Asylum Seekers Abroad While Their Cases Are Decided
description: Rights advocates swiftly condemned the new migration plan, which they say not only violates international law but also would be impossible to carry out.
content: LONDON — The British government proposed on Tuesday a plan to make it possible to transfer asylum seekers out of the country while their applications are processed and to arrest those who arrive by boat across the English Channel, policies that rights groups say would violate international laws.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Tiny Love Stories: ‘He Kissed It Better’
description: Modern Love in miniature, featuring reader-submitted stories of no more than 100 words.
content: One night in the bath, my 3-year-old accidentally stabbed me in the face with a toy unicorn. Shocked, I yelled out, causing him to cry. I hastily wrapped him in his favorite green towel. “Can I kiss it better?” I said. He shook his head. My wife removed his shrieking body, leaving me covered in soap suds and shame. The next day at breakfast, I had a small wound on my cheek. My son, covered in cereal, pointed at it and said, “You got a booboo?” I nodded. Leaning over, he kissed it better. It’s fixing, not breaking, that matters. — Ben Bernstein
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kim Severson
title: No Soil. No Growing Seasons. Just Add Water and Technology.
description: A new breed of hydroponic farm, huge and high-tech, is popping up in indoor spaces all over America, drawing celebrity investors and critics.
content: MOREHEAD, Ky. — In this pretty town on the edge of coal country, a high-tech greenhouse so large it could cover 50 football fields glows with the pinks and yellows of 30,600 LED and high-pressure sodium lights.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kevin Draper
title: Rachel Nichols Out for N.B.A. Finals Coverage on ABC
description: Comments made by Nichols that were caught on tape caused tremendous upheaval within ESPN over the past year. Nichols, who is white, suggested that a Black colleague, Maria Taylor, had been selected for a marquee job because of her race.
content: When a sideline reporter first appeared on ABC’s broadcast of the N.B.A. finals on Tuesday night, it was not Rachel Nichols, an abrupt change announced by ESPN earlier in the day. It was an attempt to stanch a yearlong scandal that has spilled into public view about the company’s handling of conflicts centered around race.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emma G. Fitzsimmons
title: Can Maya Wiley still win? It could be an uphill battle.
description: She was in third place in last week’s preliminary tally in the mayoral race and could have a difficult time overtaking her rivals.
content: Maya Wiley finished third in a preliminary tally of votes in the New York City mayor’s race last week, but she believes she still has a path to victory.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melina Delkic
title: Your Wednesday Briefing
description: Divided views on Hong Kong violence.
content: Last week, on the anniversary of Hong Kong’s handover to China, a man stabbed a police officer on a busy commercial street, then killed himself. Then, on Tuesday, the police said they had arrested nine people — including six teenagers — over alleged plots to make bombs and plant them in public areas.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dan Kaufman
title: Scott Walker’s Wisconsin Paved the Way for Donald Trump’s America
description: If Democrats want to create an enduring coalition to prevent the unraveling of democracy, they must return to their labor roots.
content: Ten years ago, after overcoming a monthslong protest movement and legal battle, a law called Act 10 took effect in Wisconsin. The nondescript name cloaked the most significant attack on labor rights since President Ronald Reagan broke the air traffic controllers union in 1981.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kellen Browning
title: Up to 1,500 businesses could be affected by a cyberattack carried out by a Russian group.
description: “It totally sucks,” said the chief executive of the software company Kaseya, which was compromised Friday along with some of its customers.
content: Between 800 and 1,500 businesses around the world were compromised or affected by a cyberattack on Friday that security experts said could be the largest attack in history using ransomware, in which hackers shut down systems until a ransom is paid.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Feuer
title: Self-Described Virginia Militiaman Is Arrested in Capitol Breach
description: Prosecutors did not charge the suspect, Fi Duong, with crimes of violence but accused him of planning to use Molotov cocktails and of conducting surveillance at the Capitol after Jan. 6.
content: In mid-June, a self-described Virginia militiaman drove with a new acquaintance from his home in Alexandria to a former prison in the nearby town of Lorton, about 15 miles away. His mission was a secret one, prosecutors say: He was scouting a location where he could test a batch of Molotov cocktails he was planning to make.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nate Cohn
title: How Convenient Should Voting Be? Court Ruling Leaves No Clear Answer
description: The Supreme Court’s decision on voting rights suggests that limits to the convenience of voting methods may be relatively permissible, while new burdens on casting a ballot in-person might be more vulnerable.
content: What kind of restrictions on voting violate Section 2 of the Voting Rights Act? That’s the basic question in the wake of the Supreme Court’s decision to uphold two Arizona voting provisions last week.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dana Rubinstein
title: Adams and Garcia have differing ideas about how the race could play out.
description: In the week between the corrected, largely symbolic first tabulation of ranked-choice votes and Tuesday, when a more substantive tabulation is set to be released, New York City voters existed in something of a news vacuum.
content: In the week between the corrected, largely symbolic first tabulation of ranked-choice votes and Tuesday, when a more substantive tabulation is set to be released, New York City voters existed in something of a news vacuum.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Laurel Graeber
title: In ‘Monsters at Work,’ the Scary Part Is the New Business Model
description: Twenty years after Pixar debuted the original “Monsters, Inc.,” Disney+ is bringing a cast of new monsters to the small screen — and putting Mike and Sulley in the managers’ office.
content: You’ve got to feel sorry for Tylor Tuskmon.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Spencer Bokat-Lindell
title: Did the Supreme Court Just Kill the Voting Rights Act?
description: For many advocates, last week's decision upholding two voting restrictions  could scarcely have come at a worse time.
content: This article is part of the Debatable newsletter. You can sign up here to receive it on Tuesdays and Thursdays.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Das
title: ‘We need the ball. We want to have it.’
description: Spain might not be the best version of itself, and it is definitely not the version, at least, that thrashed Italy, 4-0, in the final of Euro 2012. But it still plays a very Spanish style, heavy on passing and possession.
content: Spain might not be the best version of itself, and it is definitely not the version, at least, that thrashed Italy, 4-0, in the final of Euro 2012. But it still plays a very Spanish style, heavy on passing and possession.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shane Goldmacher
title: Paul LePage, former governor of Maine, aims for a comeback.
description: A Republican who shunned protocol and employed incendiary rhetoric, Mr. LePage left office with a 40 percent approval rating.
content: Paul R. LePage, the former two-term Republican governor of Maine, is planning to seek his old office again in 2022, announcing on Monday “I am in” despite having left the state for sunny Florida after his previous term ended and declaring himself done with politics.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kwame Anthony Appiah
title: How Much Must I Give Up for My Schizophrenic Brother?
description: The magazine’s Ethicist columnist on weighing a sibling’s needs against your own — and more.
content: I am in my 60s and have been married for decades. One of my brothers is moderately schizophrenic; he does well on his medication but is increasingly unable to live alone. He and I are not close and are very different people, but when our mother went into a nursing home several years ago, he came to live with my wife and me. Several other siblings living close declined to take him in.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Najim Rahim and Thomas Gibbons-Neff
title: Taliban Try to Polish Their Image as They Push for Victory
description: The insurgents are trying to rebrand themselves as effective governors as they capture new territory. But there is more evidence that they are unreformed.
content: KABUL, Afghanistan — In June, when the Taliban took the district of Imam Sahib in Afghanistan’s north, the insurgent commander who now ruled the area had a message for his new constituents, including some government employees: Keep working, open your shops and keep the city clean.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Florence Fabricant
title: An Argentine Spritz
description: Chandon’s new Garden Spritz is a citrusy, bubbly drink made in South America.
content: Chandon, the sparkling wine house, has introduced an aperitif, a light, fizzy, citrus-forward quaff that suits the season. It’s made in Argentina, one of the countries where the brand makes wines. Bitter orange is the dominant flavor but a whiff of spice adds to the charm. Drink it neat or use it to carbonate your next Negroni spritz.
source.name: The New York Times

title: The Artifacts of Bygone Lives
description: Terry Adkins’ X-ray photographs — featured in a 2021 exhibition at New York’s New Museum — offer a way to remember the dead through beloved objects.
content: Terry Adkins’ X-ray photographs — featured in a 2021 exhibition at New York’s New Museum — offer a way to remember the dead through beloved objects.
source.name: The New York Times

title: More Than the Vote
description: The suffragists’ struggle produced undaunted trailblazers, Black and white, who continued to pursue social reform.
content: The suffragists’ struggle produced undaunted trailblazers, Black and white, who continued to pursue social reform.
source.name: The New York Times

title: How Mormons Became American
description: Perpetual outsiders, Mormons spent 200 years assimilating to a certain national ideal—only to find their country in an identity crisis.
content: Perpetual outsiders, Mormons spent 200 years assimilating to a certain national ideal—only to find their country in an identity crisis.
source.name: The New York Times

title: The Black Mayors Remaking the South
description: How Black mayors in the South are leveraging both the power of office and the power of the street to achieve overdue changes.
content: How Black mayors in the South are leveraging both the power of office and the power of the street to achieve overdue changes.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Corkery
title: On the Scene: After Target Leaves
description: Target made an ambitious pledge last year: to spend $2 billion with Black-owned businesses and hire more Black employees.
content: Target made an ambitious pledge last year: to spend $2 billion with Black-owned businesses and hire more Black employees.
source.name: The New York Times

title: A Crime Writer’s Midcentury-Modern Retreat in Queens
description: In her latest crime novel, Megan Abbott takes on the contractor-client relationship. In her Queens apartment, she’s avoided renovation altogether.
content: In her latest crime novel, Megan Abbott takes on the contractor-client relationship. In her Queens apartment, she’s avoided renovation altogether.
source.name: The New York Times

title: An Open-Air Dining Room Turns to Southeast Asia
description: The seasonal restaurant Outerspace in Brooklyn is sponsoring two pop-up kitchens, one focused on Vietnamese food and the other on Cambodian cuisine.
content: The seasonal restaurant Outerspace in Brooklyn is sponsoring two pop-up kitchens, one focused on Vietnamese food and the other on Cambodian cuisine.

author: By The Associated Press
title: Watch Live: Biden Outlines Vaccination Strategy
description: President Biden delivers remarks on his administration’s coronavirus vaccination campaign to reach the tens of millions of Americans who remain unvaccinated.
content: President Biden delivers remarks on his administration’s coronavirus vaccination campaign to reach the tens of millions of Americans who remain unvaccinated.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Associated Press
title: Biden Pleads With Americans to Get Vaccinated
description: President Biden announced that nearly 160 million Americans will be fully vaccinated by the end of the week and implored all unvaccinated people to get shots, saying that they were putting their communities at risk.
content: President Biden announced that nearly 160 million Americans will be fully vaccinated by the end of the week and implored all unvaccinated people to get shots, saying that they were putting their communities at risk.

author: By The Associated Press
title: Video Shows Search-and-Rescue Effort in Condo Collapse
description: Footage from over the weekend illustrated the ongoing investigation efforts from search-and-rescue teams into the missing residents of the Surfside Condominium, which collapsed more than a week ago.
content: Footage from over the weekend illustrated the ongoing investigation efforts from search-and-rescue teams into the missing residents of the Surfside Condominium, which collapsed more than a week ago.

author: By The Associated Press
title: Watch Live: Florida Officials Give Update on Recovery Efforts
description: Officials in Surfside, Fla., provide an update on search-and-rescue efforts as Tropical Storm Elsa barrels toward the state, complicating rescue efforts.
content: Officials in Surfside, Fla., provide an update on search-and-rescue efforts as Tropical Storm Elsa barrels toward the state, complicating rescue efforts.

author: By The New York Times
title: Tropical Storm Elsa Pushes Strong Winds and Rain Into Florida
description: After causing heavy rain and flooding in Cuba, Tropical Storm Elsa passed near the Florida Keys and was expected to approach hurricane strength before making landfall early Wednesday.
content: After causing heavy rain and flooding in Cuba, Tropical Storm Elsa passed near the Florida Keys and was expected to approach hurricane strength before making landfall early Wednesday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dara Kell and Veena Rao
title: A Ship From Guantánamo
description: Moath al-Alwi has never been charged with a crime, but has spent over 19 years at the U.S. military detention camp in Cuba. In a new short film, see the art he makes to survive.
content: Moath al-Alwi has never been charged with a crime, but has spent over 19 years at the U.S. military detention camp in Cuba. In a new short film, see the art he makes to survive.

description: Readers recount their travel experiences, good and bad. Also: Clemency and the pandemic.
